These grain bins appear simple, but a number of things require very special attention.
For Instance, make sure the product, people marketing it and assembling the darn thing are good at it.
ANY opening, especial a door or vent in the roof MUST be installed and SEALED correctly to keep out any form of moisture that can spoiling the contents.
Auger systems that move the grain, especially if they are built in / internal must be carefully vetted before buying and function checked thoroughly for strength and endurance regularly.

Concerning your own corn crop, try arranging your rows more concentrated for better pollination.  In other words shorter and wider.  Sixteen short rows better than eight long ones.

I wish you went into the inventory side of it because you of all people would LOVE how it works.

To measure how much grain are in the bins, they use radar level sensors. They use a radar beam to measure the distance from the top of the bin to the top of the grain (as you can imagine, it's not always flat so now they also have 3D imaging devices as well) which is then converted into volume.

The company who makes 90% of those sensors is "BinMaster". They also make an inventory system for the farmers so that they can get all their bin capacity info on a single computer so they can sew everything (they call it "BinView")

It's definitely something Dustin would be interested in learning about!! Especially how it all communicates and what not.

Neat video on grain bins. However, only a small portion soybean production will be used as food for humans it will mostly be used as animal feed, fuel and other industrial uses. The verity’s of soy being produced in that field isn’t the edamame you eat in a restaurant. Only a small portion of field corn grain is consumed by humans in the form of corn syrup i.e. coke, pepsi, Mt. Dew etc. (which is a multi step complex process), breakfast cereal or corn starch. The majority of field corn is used for Ethanol production, animal feed and manufacturing. The problem is we are told these field grains are for us to eat but actually it is more likely to be sold abroad, fuel your car or feed the beef or chicken you eat. It also degrades our soil. 2 crop rotation is not sustainable. My uncle and grandpa have a very large grain operation near Des Moines IA and 30 years ago as a kid I would help with annual soil sampling and we could easily get deep samples. Now pushing for a deep sample is not a job a kid can do sadly because of erosion. The worms and ground bacteria that promote healthy top soil are devastated by pesticides sadly so they have to put down more chemicals to feed the crops. Sorry for the long sad comment I am just passionate about this subject.
-Mike
Lead grower of a produce farm in Iowa.

My uncle was the "poorest" man in the county... Not only did he run his own farm, but the crops he raised were mainly to feed his sheep herds over winter...
He didn't sell any of his crops they simply fed the sheep over winter...

One year it was "so bad"... He couldn't order a new truck, so he had to wait to the next year...

Usually he would order a new sheep herding truck for himself, every 2 years... But one year it was "so bad" he had to wait...

He didn't sell crops, he only sold wool, to the United States government because of a contract he had... And he sold lambs and mutton.

That One year it was "so bad", he had to end up selling 50% of his lambs instead of 35%...

The $4 million he got (from just selling his lambs, remember not including the mutton for the wool) covered the operation costs of his 13 sheep camps with his 40 paid sheep herder employees (didn't include the 27 dogs...)

Things were "pretty tough" because you see, when he ordered a new truck for himself, he would move the "old" truck to one of the sheep camps and they, in turn, would move their "old" truck to one of the other sheep camps...

And then he would take that extra truck...

And sell it for used.

So everybody "suffered" that year...

But if you asked him, he was the "dirt poorest man" in the whole county... He was so poor he didn't know what to do with himself...

And of course my family had five kids living off of government rations because my dad worked for the federal government...

But we were "spoiled" cuz we got our "food for free"

while my uncle had to pay for his...

And he hardly had two nickels to rub together according to him...

Which I guess was probably true...

because he didn't have nickels

they were $1,000 bills.

"We not very smart" translates to if not for us the world would die. Farmers are the pioneers that never died. Try this, grow a garden to sustain yourself for an entire year. 4:30 you really dont realize how handy those large punches are until your on a job site like this. I used to build large fabric buildings such as the half circle shaped fabric buildings commonly seen at DOT facilities especially in snowy states where they use fabric buildings to store their road salt. some of the trusses would be 60 feet wide and 30 feet tall, multiple thousand pounds, hoisted up on a forklift. So it can get pretty tough to line up your bolt holes to line up, but with a punch we would just stick it in the second bolt hole then by applying pressure up or down you could move the massive truss enough to line up your other hole and get a bolt through

In regards to repairing farming equipment, the farmers use every tool they can but companies like John Deere make it a royal pain to do many repairs and directly oppose Right to Repair proposals. Although right to repair already exists in the consumer automotive industry, it doesn't exist for any computers or applicably to this video, farming equipment. This means that companies can prevent farmers from buying repair tools and equipment and force them to pay the manufacturer to do repairs which can lead to weeks of equipment downtime during periods where they absolutely need that equipment running. To combat this anti-competitive and anti-consumer business practice, please consider supporting right to repair in your state or country. What you do to your property is none of their business but many corporations have quite literally made it their business to control the life cycle of your property.

True story:  My brother and I were on a business sales call with a young engineer.  Around 1998?  Played a round of golf and were having a nice lunch.  Talking background, he described growing up on the farm.  His father/family still farmed. He slipped in, "You all might think that farmin' is easy, but...."  We both looked at each other and went (!?@?!).  We were second gen away from the farm, older than this kid, and our uncles all left the family farm.  Because it was too tough!  We had grown up with horrific tales of weather collapses, bankruptcy, long hours with the livestock, children dying because the hospital was too far away, market fluctuations.... you get the idea.  We assured him we didn't think, "farmin' be easy", and then laughed about his perception for months, afterward.  When any situation went sideways, we would look at each other and say, "Farmin ain't easy!  Ha, ha!!! Only a dingbat thinks farming is easy.  Toughest job on earth. (sorry, President of the United States of America)

13:00 their have been people i know killed by entering a bin to un-plug a clog....
.
1st dude goes in, grain "falls" covering them up.....
2nd person goes in..... they also get trapped
3rd person goes in...... they also get trapped
.
like 8 hours later.... someone notices they arnt around for lunch....
heads out to look for them
.
finds 3 vehicles around the grain bin
.
looks inside the bin..... and only sees blood..... from the auger ripping all 3 of them apart
.
.
that a TRUE story..... and it happens ALL AROUND the world
in NE montana..... or Russia, Germany, China, ETC
.
your just trying to save your friend (or more usually.... a close family member.... AKA your dad.... brother... sister....cousin....ETC)
and end up getting trapped / killed yourself
.
and then someone else trys to save you....
and gets killed....
.
vicious circle.......................
.
.
.
their are actually a few different "rescue" tools..... specifically designed to rescue people from grain bins
.
one is 4 to 5 pieces of a circle....
you hammer them down into the grain..... forming a circle around the person trapped
you then can empty the grain from inside the "metal circle"
with out more grain coming down and filling the hole you have been digging back up
.
it still takes an hour or 2
.
and even if your head is above the grain
all that pressure is still pushing on your body
.
so you may have your head in "clear air"
but the grain pressure is such..... that you arnt strong enough to move your chest (AKA.... breath)
.
so you die... not being able to breath..... as your whole family / friends / work crew can see your lips turn blue
and then the look in your eyes as you finally die...
.
.
farming is HARD CORE

1:45 another force..... if the grain gets wet, it expands
ive seen (and heard!) grain bins EXPLODING because of the pressure
.
and you NEVER go into a bin to "un-clog" it
.
MANY people have been buried alive and died from the grain falling down and covering them
.
it "drains" from the center out....usually (their are different styles of bin.... and different machines that empty the bin)
but sometimes they plug up (if the grain is a BIT moist.... it can clump together and clog)
.
so you see this big "cone" of grain..... and you see the clog
so your just gonna hop in threw the roof.... and kick the clog with your boot.... or a pole
.
and then the "air pocket" collapses...... you drop 5 feet..... and the grain from above fills in around you (sometimes over your head)
then you suffocate in a pile of grain
.
or... you leave the machine running..... and you end up getting chopped into pieces
.
.
and if you didnt tell anyone you were going inside that bin.....
you might be their for 2 WEEKS!!! till someone finds you
.
its happened before..... and will happen almost every year
.
farming is dangerous...... you have HEAVY machines with a LOT of power behind them
tons of cutting edges..... and your out in the field for 16 hours (OR MORE!!!) per day
.
tired + heavy + power + sharp things = bad things happen quickly

Fascinating. I grew up in Iowa, where my grandfather and several uncles all had farms. From birth thru college, I spent tons of time on those farms. Your soy bean harvesting, storage and sales coverage brought back some great memories.

My grandfather’s bins did not have that rotating auger underneath. So when we were emptying a bin, the center of the beans would quickly draw down, forming a cone. Because it didn’t have that auger, the sides of the cone had to be manually knocked down to keep the process going. Believe it or not, I recall working around the inside perimeter of those bins, with a couple of my cousins, to kick down the sides toward the center cone. I was maybe 12 or 13. In hind site it was definitely dangerous, but we were only doing the same things our fathers did, growing up on that farm.

All that said, the grain bin construction footage was new to me; I’ve never seen one built. Given my upbringing and the fact I’ve been a professional civil engineer (P.E.) for over 35 years, I particularly enjoyed this part of your video. That jacking process is a genius solution to building higher and higher without a crane or major scaffolding.

Great stuff; love your channel! Keep doing what your doing!

I always marvel at how easy it is to take super complex things for granted. To be fair, your brain can only handle so much at a time, but a lot of people just never ask questions about all this crazy stuff around them.

My dad farmed for 60 years and I grew up working for/with him. I thought he could do anything and he amazed me at his audacious attitude about dismantling things, repairing,  and reassembling them. He was a young teenager when farming was becoming more mechanized and was told by his father that he was responsible for making everything function. He learned by doing. By asking old we mechanics. Thank the Lord that a small part of that rubbed off on me. Cotton pickers. Combines. Tractors. Mowers. Trucks. Cars. Motorcycles. ATVs.  He could machine, weld, fabricate, plumb, and was a great electrician.
My Grandsons first job was building bins here in Missouri . Now he's a Contractor on his own .
So that's what the inside of sn8 looks like

The sheer amount of ways I tried to wrap my head around building that grain bin was astounding. Thinking like "maybe they make supports, then wrap a big piece of steel around it" and other things like that. Then to see them BUILD IT FROM THE TOP DOWN ... That really blew my mind, and I've already seen this video when it came out...

Seriously, you think farming is easy and all that, but it is the soul of logistics. You think "Oh, it's just a tractor and something attached to it". And maybe you play or see someone playing Farming Simulator, going for the largest tractor with tank treads everything and think that's really unrealistic. But then you realise, that that is probably an under exaggeration if anything. Farming is incredibly high tech nowadays, and you may think that farmers are dumb, and don't know anything about "modern" technology.

But you stated it perfectly Destin, they're probably the smartest of us all.

Thanks for this Dustin, this made me realize how lazy and uninformed my thoughts on farmers were. I studied agriculture at UC Davis and live in a rural area surrounded by farms (my dad even has a small acre farm as a hobby), but I was still prey to the "farmers are humble uneducated country folk" trope.
They have one of the hardest jobs out there, rigorous and demanding work on an unforgiving schedule while doubling as an accountant on the side, all for a pittance of a profit margin, if any.

I think it's crucial that we protect them and their future livelihoods by regulating the multinational Ag and food conglomerates that bleed them dry and force them to farm in the least sustainable manner all in the name of profit that they don't share. Farmers should be in control of their own crops and prices, they deserve to be making their fair share. Meanwhile the substantial work to reform agriculture to a sustainable practice in America needs to be undertaken in a way that doesn't unfairly burden farmers or the American taxpayer, but holds Big Ag responsible.

Farmers are the bedrock of Public health and American business, even if we don't realize it. They should be treated like it.

I actually read about this technique for the first time a long while ago, in Julius Cesar book on the Roman civil war: "Commentarii de Bello Civili". Read the translation, of course.

Caesar's engineers used this technique (build a low layer for the wall, raise it and add another layer under, do it again) to build towers around the city of Marseille, under siege. It allowed them to keep their builders protected from the city defenders.

in regard to your corn crop, corn is a self pollinating crop and relies on the close spacing of the plants so that the pollen, when released, waffles between the plants and hence germinates as many of the kernels as possible .

fun fact - the moisture tester at 11:20 is actually just a capacitor, with one plate on the underside of the lid, and one plate at the bottom of the canister. when the canister is filled, the grain acts as a dielectric, and all other necessary info remaining constant (distance between the plates, type of grain used, etc.), water's presence changes the extent to which a given grain acts as a dielectric within the capacitor, which is how you get the moisture readout 🌺

I'm sure someone else noticed this, but that's not a punch.  It's called an alignment drift.  Punches are varying in size and typically straight-sided.  The drift in the video is being used for exactly what it is designed to do. 😁

There is a big reason that your corn doesn't do as well as that on a farm - because your corn is "sweet corn", not "field corn" or "silage corn"; you also don't have the specific chemicals that the farmers use to get the corn off to a good start.  Although farmers are relatively smart, don't over estimate -- modern farmers have a LOT OF HELP from federal and state agriculture departments who provide them with best planting times, soil analysis which includes providing what and how much minerals, chemicals, fertilizers to use and when, insect control, etc.  It also helps to have hundreds of thousands to millions of dollars worth of automated machinery for soil prep, planting, fertilizing, cultivating, harvesting, etc.  Like the first guy said when he was testing the soybeans for moisture, he doesn't know how it works, he just knows it does.  Then like the other guy said, he has a good accountant, a guy who does the marketing, etc.  The biggest problem with starting out farming is MONEY, most of these larger farms are multi-generational, been in the family for generations and these guys learned a lot working on their farms before eventually taking them over.  They have been using this machinery for years and KNOW what usually goes wrong and are most often simple fixes, but when the electronics breaks or major parts break, they do have technicians/mechanics that they call to make repairs.               (I'm a very small independent farmer).

I have an engineering question. Why do the corrugated lines run horizontally and not vertically? I would think the corrugation would be used to hold up the weight of the roof and the pressure of the walls above each section. Like pressure in the oceans, wouldn't the pressure on the sections closest to the floor be the most extreme? The way it's built with them going horizontally, it seems like that would encourage the whole thing to crumple downward with gravity. But if the corrugated metal ran vertically it would be much stronger, much harder to crush from the top down. What am I missing here? What mechanical advantage is gained by making the corrugation run horizontally? It's not like this thing can twist. Or can it? At 13:59, for about a few seconds, there's another metal building in the background and it's corrugated lines go vertically the way I'd expect. Most handheld moisture testers (like the one at 11:20) measure the capacitance between two plates within the sample chamber. Moisture reduces this capacitance.
Knowing the type of grain being tested along with tight calibration on the unit allows reasonably accurate measurements of moisture. There are other, more advanced systems, used elsewhere in the industry. I used to be a technician at a plant which manufactures moisture testers.

I construct Grain Bins for a living... flattering to know I'm basically an engineer... 😂 biggest bin my crew's built, is a 101,000 bushel bin. 54 feet in diameter, and 13 rings (tiers) high. Each ring is 44 inches high. So 47.6 feet high, not including the roof. Honestly Destin, I learnt some new things from this video, and I've been building these bins for 4 years. If You ever stop by southern Alberta, hit me up, and come join our crew. (We could use some free labor now and then. 😉 watch out for pranks though... it's a group of 9 guys, most of which like to mess around with the newbie. 😄)  We have a slightly differant routine, but the basic principles are the same.

You cannot be dumb and be a farmer. Destin is absolutely correct. Farmers are some of the smartest people there are because of the numerous overlapping and interacting disciplines required in both their planning and in day to day operations. One of my first jobs was erecting grain bins. One thing not mentioned here is that the evaporation of the moisture from the grain works just as when you step from a shower. Instant cooling. So the evaporating moisture reduces the temperature significantly thereby helping reduce the likelihood of bacteria and fungal growth. The first wave of the air plenum type bins was called Harvestall, and was invented by a Dr. Stephens in Cedar Rapids, IA. The Harvestall bins I helped build were done in 1977.

I believe that they've seen enough go wrong that they understand (like we all should) that we're just a step away from greatness AND abject failure. I grew up in Iowa... my dad sold and erected  grain bins.. I  started on the erection crew at 8 years old... there os sooo much science in grain harvesting and storage. There are many more  systems involved in grain storage and drying than are  talked about in  this video.  Grain bins are always built from the top down, whether it be with Jack's or a boom truck... you build the first 'ring' and the roof and and add  rings from there. In the media farmers are portrayed as simpletons.... truth is that however  humble they  claim .... they are hundreds times smarter than  any politician  whether  Democrat or Republican... they are managing 50 to a 100 times  more data than  an politician could comprehend  in a lifetime. a punch is a tool that's used for an entirely different purpose, in the case of manual operation usually in conjunction with a hammer. what you are using is called a 'drift' . in your case the one you are using is a single point drift, they also come in double point, the other end being a shorter more stubby taper or the other end can have an angled chiseled end similar to a pry bar or crow/jemmy bar. drifts come in all shapes and sizes and are used in the construction industry for assembling the structural beams that hold and support buildings together.

I know a guy around where I grew up that used to check out old grain bins for defects. Seals, bolts, and interior ring wear. One time he was inside of one of my neighbors bins, he opened the top lid, saw it was full, and went inside to take a look. The bin he was in was an old SuKup, probably 50’ tall by 28’ wide. He walked on top of the grain, checking for rust spots along the seams. He didn’t see anything, and went into my neighbors house to tell him that the bin was in great shape. My neighbor, looked at him with astonishment and told him that the bin he had walked in, 45’+ feet in the air on the inside, hadn’t been used in almost 12 years. The guy had walked on a 3” thick layer of crusted beans, with nothing underneath him. That bin hadn’t been filled in years, but the crust on top is what the guy had walked on, not knowing about the massive void underneath him. Grain bins are a scary implement.

at 12:41 these guys do something incredibly dangerous. That auger circles around like an agitator so there is no right side it will come towards you. You are dependent on a machine not breaking down. The auger doesn't necessarily have to continue in the direction of the pile of grain it can hop back towards you. In my case it moved into what you guys called the safe area more than 6 feet.


We had a farm with this system and the auger had hopped over the grain. I went in the bin with the auger. Shoveled the grain over into the auger. My thinking was that with my foot securely on the end the auger bearing so things would be good. Then the auger moved counter clockwise backing away from me. I was lucky enough to notice and use my shovel as a wedge under it to stop it when it changed directions again moving clockwise. So there is no emergency stop inside the bin for that auger because manufactures believe you will never enter the bin with that thing running. Because its happened to me I know behind it is not a safe area they can malfunction and move backward.


Having said that, farming often involves comprises 'safety' with 'getting things done'. If you check many guards are missing as the equipment frequently plugs and repairs go on until: "it will work this way lets get back to work". Careful distance touring the farm yard equipment like pto's and augers. We never had an injury that wasn't able to cover up and say yup all good here didn't happen - farmer's pride - but we got real close a number of times. If you are touring a farm know that farmers themselves with good experience and being careful are getting injured and killed by pto's and augers its a frequent injury happening on the farm.

Your corn needed water pretty bad... when the leaves roll up like that the plants are water stressed... Looked like it was planted a little thick or some doubles (two or more seeds planted close together) neither is good for corn, because it's a very population-sensitive crop (other corn plants too close tend to "cannibalize" nutrients from each other, no neither makes a good ear). I trust you're planting a good sweet corn variety here for ear corn. Looks like you could use some nitrogen fertilizer as well to supplement the soil; corn likes plenty of nitrogen and phosphate (phosphorus) and a bit of sulfur never hurts either (usually). Water was definitely the limiting factor, when the leaves roll up it's already hurting for water pretty bad. If it had enough water the leaves wouldn't roll up like that and the color would tell you a lot about the plant's health and nutrient needs-- usually if it's a light green or yellowish is a sure sign it needs more nitrogen. IF it's dark green it'll be healthy and have all the nutrients it needs to make a good crop. If you have too many plants or plant seeds too thick (overpopulation) you can always thin it out by pulling up some of the plants so they're no closer than about 6-8 inches apart. In dry conditions or poor soil nutrient availability, planting no closer than about 12 inches apart (or more) will allow each plant more soil to obtain nutrients and water to make a crop, but of course the lower population means less plants to produce ears, so it's a tradeoff... that's why farmers in different areas with different climates, weather patterns, heat or high temps in summer, thinner soils, sandier soils (which hold less water for shorter periods of time before drying out) plant different populations (seeds per acre or unit of area).
Best of luck on your corn for next year! OL J R :)

I think I get where Destin is coming from. He's a smart guy who views the world with a curious and analytical eye. He looks at tools we use on a regular basis and is amazed by the marvel of engineering, where many of us discount them as things that get the job done without thinking twice about how they work. Destin can't help but see that there's a lot of complex systems working together that make it all work. That's just how his mind works. He sees these complex systems and thinks, "these people must be geniuses," but a lot of these folks view it with a much narrower scope. They don't see the same complexity and nuance that Destin sees.
I'm not saying that there aren't very smart people among farmers, because I'm sure there are. All I'm saying is I get why Destin thinks these folks are geniuses, when really many of them aren't. It helps him feel empathetic towards them if he imagines that they see the world the way he does, which is a noble effort, but I think that on some level it's still a lie that he tells himself. And that's okay.

Wow! Flashback to my teens in the later '70's on a farm in south-central Minnesota. I finally found a subject that I knew better than Destin! :) We had a similar bin setup but the blower on one of the bins had a propane heater incorporated so we could use it for drying corn. It also had an auger that optionally went up the center of the pivot to cycle grain from the bottom to the top of the bin. I also worked for a company in the summer of '79 that sold not just bins but whole grain systems that weren't covered in this video. These grain 'legs' are the big Christmas tree shaped structures that hover above a set of bins. I helped with everything from the concrete work for the swimming pool type of dump pits at the base of the leg and bin slabs, to the steel work and leg down chute branches... Very interesting and dangerous job but my monkey climbing years are behind me now. However, I did not jack bins or operate the cranes and we did not have the handy electric tools back then.

There is a LOT of technology involved in modern farming.  My very first interaction with a computer was the guy at the local Department of Agriculture branch doing soil analysis for us and we would go in and get a printout from him that told us the health of our soil and what we might do to improve it. sooooooo, I guess bushels are another weird imperial unit type of thingy, which apparently are 35.24 liters.
Gallon, pints, fluid ounces, quarts, barrels and acre foots seem not to be enough volume measurements.

Oh, wait, those were the liquid measurement ones, for dry stuff it's barrel, peck, gallon, quart and pint (which of course are completely different of the fluid ones even if they have the same name).
The conversions at least are somewhat consistent with the dry measurements, with a bushel consisting (mostly) out of powers of 2 of the other stuff (peck 4, gallon 8, quart 32, pint 64, barrel 0.3048 (ouch)).

Not to detract from farmers in any way, but it's not like they just invented the grain bin overnight fully formed. It evolved over, literally, thousands of years as humans have been farming for a long time and the need to store grain has existed since the start. I guess this is the scientific method personified. Hey, let's build a thing to store our grain in. Oh, problem x exists. Okay, how can we fix that? Eventually solve that issue, on to the next one. Hey, someone invented a thing and I think it could improve our grain bins. And you end up where we are today. Farmers are absolutely innovators having had to solve fairly unique issues on the fly on their own largely.

I've grown up in farmland.. my grandpa was a farmer, I've been out there many many times growing up! I've never seen how those bins were made tho.. they had tiny bins that were there before my time, and larger bins that were transported in as whole from the neighbors. never saw how they were actually made tho! Also... I've had much experience with harvest, with beans and also corn. Beans usually went straight into the bins. But the corn.. it would go from the grain truck or gravity boxes, and it would go into a dryer which would dry it first, and then from there it would be augered into the bins! we also had these devices which we would collect a small sample from a spout that we would push in and it would spit out the sample into the cup, and we would slowly pour it into the reader which would tell us if it was dry enough or not. My mom's cousin was also a grain trucker.. I rode with him many MANY times in my teen years! The truck loading, the auger at the bottom of the bin.. it's all VERY familiar with me! I love this video so much, it brings back so many memories!  Thank you so much for this video!

Took me back 30+ years... I have done all this only we built a Harvestore which is a silo, not a grain bin. Silos need to be airtight and Harvestore panels are coated in some kind of glass and sealed with a special tar. The panels are lifted like this only the jacks turn the whole thing exactly 1 bolt hole to the right, for some reason. I never rode in a combine, but drove a mounted 2 row picker as well as driving the tractor pulling the 2 row picker when the mounted one broke. We put corn up on the ear in open air bins and fed livestock out of them until right before harvest the next year, when the price was high, then we ran out the ears and shelled it. We put silage into a pit and covered it before that, and fed it out during winter after it had fermented a few months. AHH the sweet smelling steam from the silage when you fed it out... The cows came running to get their fix from the silage pit. The guy I worked for did it the old fashioned way on a small farm. Few people today know the old ways I learned there... I cherish those memories. AH to be 18 again working the farm... I didn't know how much fun I was having...

Find yourself a manufacturer of coffins (yes, the final resting place kind), see how they produce the milled boards on 12 axle milling machines and how important dust and chip removal is to their productivity and their safety. The fan you saw there was an average fan in a crappy housing. Find a company that sells and installs central dust collection systems and ask them to show you a working system. You'll see fans that will easily eat you up. Interesting bonus facts to put in that video, would be channel collapse (when the vacuum gets too high due to sudden inlet blockage, a vacuum shock can dent the first tube and if the vacuum is not shut off, the tube will collapse, causing a domino effect collapsing the entire channel), dust explosions and safety measures (controlled explosion directing), transport fans (fans that pass the chips through the blades get a serious beating on the inside of their housing, and will eventually wear and rip no matter how durable the steel and how soft the wood). I used to be a design engineer for such systems, and what looks like just some tubes and a collection bin, is in fact a balanced system of fans, sensors, a lot of calculations (nozzle shapes and sizes, duct sizes, splits and branches, filtering surface, combustibility, etc). Definitely worth your time and attention...

I was a town kid too but I'm lucky enough to have gone to school with farm kids and spent plenty of time seeing how their farms operated (dairy farms not grain, but there's plenty of mechanical effort in milking machines and refrigerated raw milk storage too).

Any farmer who can last more than a season has to be able to handle any one of a hundred different problems, mostly without outside help. And they're so modest about it. If civilisation crashed and burned, these guys would be some of the few people who would carry on just fine.

Also I'm a chemical engineer and that bit where you were showing the grain being dried is an example of an desorption process. That moving wave of a drying zone with dry behind it and wet ahead of it is a classic feature of adsorption/desorption processes. So there's a bit of chemical engineering going on at that farm too.

A topic close to my heart Destin. I've made my career around agriculture for the last 30 years and farmers are some of the best people on the planet and some of the smartest and most humble. This really hits home on a year like we are having where in my area we have almost nothing planted and a majority of my customers will not have any crops to harvest. To give you an idea, my boss and I were talking about the current planting season which normally would be long over by now. There are currently 31 million acres un-planted in the US farm belt. Doing a little math I told my boss "OK, 31 million acres, divide that by 640 (acres in a sq mile) take the sq root of that and you have a square 220 miles by 220 miles with nothing in the ground" ~ just this afternoon talking with one of our good customers he planted 30 acres of corn on sandy gravel back in April- he won't turn another wheel this season.  - As for those grain bins, they are one of the most dangerous things on a farm or at an elevator. In my time in my location I can recall at least 3 people who have died being trapped in bins - It is a complete and absolute sin to climb into a bin where the grain has bridged up- It is worse than quicksand. Nice topic! I couldn't figure out how you were going to do 15 minutes on grain bins but you hit it all man, great job! A TON of information packed in there on such a mundane topic, but you always make it so interesting- Pretty good for a science nerd my man!

A little bit more info for you guys which I learned during my ENG senior design project.


Basically when grain spoils, it starts to release heat, and when it heats up it spoils faster. When grain sits in the bins, it naturally forms hotspots where localized areas start to spoil. If left unchecked, the grain can actually get hot enough for the hotspots to spontaneously combust. (grain is REALLY flammable)


Farmers need to climb on top of the bins and manually probe the grain in order to measure its temperature to try to catch the hotspots before they get out of control. But this is really dangerous because they could fall in and be crushed or suffocate (because decaying grain releases CO2 and its heavier than air)


We designed and built a prototype solution to solve some of it but I wont bore you guys with the details. (unless you're curious)

Instead of 3 long rows of corn, try squares of 6-7 rows of corn. Instead of doing rows with lots of plants and then 18 inch spacing between rows, do a perfect grid of plants every 10-12 inches in both directions. You've got excess plants in your rows. Thin to 1 plant every 10 inches.

Why the dense spacing? Because the female and male parts of corn are at very different places on the plant and the pollen blows from one row to the next row. By packing your plants in a grid, you increase the chance of pollination. I actually hand-pollinate by cutting off flowers early in the morning and shaking them on the tassels. A ridiculous idea if you have acres of corn, but in a home garden it's time well spent.

Finally, fertilizer. Corn is not a vegetable. It is a grass. Fertilize with very strong nitrogen fertilizer (30-0-0 or 45-0-0) 1/2 tsp per plant when it is 1 foot tall and again at 4 feet tall. Good luck!

When you see a large wrench used in heavy construction generally they have a pointed handle. For years I did not understand this, not ergonomic and why not have another wrench head like automotive wrenches. It is called a spud wrench and that handle is used to align bolt or rivet holes of large beams, just like the punch. (Some heavy construction wrenches have a block handle, this is a hammer wrench and the block is for striking with a machinist hammer or sledge for final tightening or loosening)

My dad is a farmer, both my grandpas, three of my great-grandpas, and about all of the rest of my ancestors are farmers. It's hard work and often being a farmer is being confused with a hired hand. My dad is the one doing all of the decision making and has to know a lot of things about biology, chemistry, economics, engineering, mechanics, and everything else I'm forgetting.
Also- I'm glad he mentioned the danger of grain bins. Even though my family has been farming in our area for 8 generations, every farmer I know has had a close call while in a grain bin. So every now and then my job calls for me to have to work alongside farmers. I work at a telecommunications infrastructure engineering firm in Chicago and occasionally I have to go to the field as an inspector for projects when construction calls for it. This one time I had to go to a place in southern Illinois that required our client lower the fiber optic line that was in an old steel pipeline (previously used for gas) that was just too shallow for the farmers comfort. They said their equipment kept hitting the steel potentially damaging the teeth. We get there to do the work, this farmer was so irate and pissed off like you wouldn't believe! He was pissed because he saw that we were gonna do this work right after a day it had rained. He was afraid that the tracks on the equipment my guys needed to use would destroy the ground his crops need to grow on. Once we got started he saw how fine everything was and became the nicest guy in the field all of a sudden. Even shuttled me back and forth from the site to my car via 4-wheeler alongside his dog. But you could tell this guy knew a lot about a lot like you said in this video. And by the way, he and several other farmers I've talked to really, REALLY dislike being in big cities like Chicago lol.

Hey Destin. What these guys are calling a "punch" is generally referred to as an awl. Generally speaking, mechanics use them for the purpose of aligning holes - like when mating transmissions to engines, for example.

Conversely, a "punch" or "hole punch" (correct nomenclature) is used for punching holes in stuff. Though technically, by definition, neither term "awl" or "punch" are specifically defined as "alignment tools," generally speaking, if you go to any shop and ask for an "awl," they'll know you want to align holes. Ask for a "punch," and they will give you something designed to be hit with a hammer.

The way to tell them apart, an awl is tapered. Though a punch CAN be tapered, they generally are not.

Harvesters don't actually need to wait for an auger to empty a larger grain wagon or a semi. There's an invention called a DumPit, which is essentially a pit that grain is dumped into and elevated over time. Having the pit instead of just an auger allows for grain to be unloaded as fast as it can escape its container, instead of how fast the auger operates. The pit can be a certain ratio smaller than the container it accepts grain from, which is related to the speed of the auger versus the speed of emptying the container. Once the container empties, a sensor, a timer, or manual intervention can shut it off - while the grain wagon is long gone.

I worked at the largest grain elevator in my area for 3 years in high school and boy oh boy was it some hard work, but was also quite eye opening as to the actual business of farming.
We primarily took in Corn, Soybeans, and wheat, but since we also had a feed mill onsite so we also took in smaller amounts of things like oats, ear corn, and other grains used in making custom livestock feed.


You're watching them sweep out a 50,000 bushel bin, that's an easy one, we didn't have a bin that was smaller than 100,000 and our 2 largest were 350,000-400,000 bushels,but you go to an actual grain terminal that ships by rail or barge and you'll see bins that hold 1,000,000 and up.


You were discussing the forces involved in storing large amounts of grain, on of the thing you didn't discuss was grain bin wall collapse.
On a lot of bins especially the tall ones, you'll see that the have equally spaced reinforcing bars running vertically around the outside diameter of a bin to help stop a wall collapse on a bin.


Also something to consider is dust particle explosions, you ALWAYS make sure that any electrical connection to the sweep auger motor INSIDE the bin is tight, and fully covered to prevent sparks to help avoid an explosion from dust ignition.

In Russia the military removes all moisture from the air by using a direct drive all mechanical electro-mechanical diesel engine driven (coal gas, natural gas, biogas, wood gas can also be used with a little adjustment in the controls) atmospheric water generator pump the super dry air right through the wheat grains or any grain or any bean at all. And then use the super dry air to dry the grains and beans. But most of the time the grains and beans are liquid nitrogen sprayed and placed inside a vacuum chamber which is also the grain silo where the air is pumped out constantly until the grains and beans are all dried up and the vacuum is constantly maintained indefinitely.

They will grow in fairly poor soil, are drought-resistant once established, and the seeds are a nearly-perfect food. This type is also "heirloom", not hybrid, so you are not locked into buying new seeds every year. Just save a fraction of your crop and plant them. And for small fields that will be tended by human hands, you can also grow beans and gourds/squash in the same soil at the same time, "3 sisters" style. The bean roots provide nitrogen to all 3 crops, and the gourds shade the ground, reducing water use and soil erosion. ... Old School Farming!

This sets America and other top developed countries apart from the developing or undeveloped world. In many nations in Africa, for instance, the people live from one crop to another because they have no long term storage ability. I've watched hundreds of laborers repeatedly carrying large (200#) bags of corn or beans out of a shed to pour them out on tarps to dry in the sun. They rake it around constantly to get the most sun exposure, then toward the end of the day they have to shovel it all back in bags to carry it inside under the roof. Simply the humidity from the air can be too much moisture and rot an entire crop.
And thus, you have starvation when there is a single drought season. Most people in America are unaware how much grain is stored and how little a drought year impacts the grocery store or livestock operations. We take our grocery stores for granted and few realize the size of investment and the skill that goes into stocking those stores.

Both my parents grew up in a farm. Half of their 13 brothers (both families combined) are still farmers. My dad worked the fields from 8 to 25 and my mom moved to the city for college since she was 22.
When I was 13, my father bought a patch of land because he was afraid he was going to lose his job as a policeman for a crime he didn't commit (Long story short, a fellow policeman of my father was shot and killed, the murderer's son was tortured by a handful of policemen, cried a river on the media and the command decided to criminally indict every single cop in the nearby region. It's military law, crimes commited by policemen are seen as a smear on the institution, so it's far harsher than civilian law. Presumption of innocence doesn't exist in it), so he decided to grow wathever he could. And employed the whole family to do it. Mostly me.

It was hard work. I hated every single second of it, except when I got to drive the tractor. The land was so small we barely employed mechanization, just the occasional time dad rented a tractor to till the land and move produce. We farmed "organic", without using pesticides or defensives. About 40% of our crops were lost to crop diseases, but thankfully the "organic" fad was spooling up, so we sold our stuff at a premium. We still barely made a profit.

As I grew up, my dad was cleared of charges against him and I started my apprenticeship at 17, moving out to college at 18. Eventually, I started to put great value on my short farming experience and started seeing things differently. I'll always be a city boy, but I see how city people takes things for granted. They often think growing stuff is just throwing seeds in the ground. No. Farming is complicated. You have to at the very least take into account weather, season, soil conditions and what you can and cannot grow. You simply can't grow cocoa beans in temperate climates, just as a starter. If you have a land with a gradient mild enough to allow mechanization, you will have to know how to fix those machines, because you can't call a repairman in the middle of nowhere or tow a harvester from the middle of a field (well, sometimes you just have to do it. Even at the cost of trampling some crop). Then there's all the complexity of seeds and storing produce. Most seed nowadays were the results of crossbreeds that make them sterile once they give fruit. So you can't just store a portion of the harvest to use as seeds.

Massive respect for farmers. Us city slickers wouldn't last a week doing what they do.

When I listen to the farm reports in the morning I am amazed at just how INVOLVED farming truly is.  All of the variables in weather, field conditions for planting and harvesting, estimates at cost per acre and yields, economic balancing of the market vs storage and availability, foreign government purchasing/selling of grains and balancing the purchasing of new equipment or maintenance of equipment in inventory.  It just amazes me at how complicated farming is and the intellect of the farming community as a whole is amazing!

I work in such a company, that pretty much does everything this video has shown. The reality is that it is more complicated than the video shows and that it is a seasonal job, which makes it really tiresome. Repairing is not always a thing because in modern tractors and harvesters there are so many advanced technology that limits you a lot. You also need the schematics of the machine to be able to do a repair or to calibrate things correctly. Even then experience is everything, because decades after buying a harvester, the company may still hasn't corrected the errors in their maintenance and repair documents. There are also tricks to make the drying process faster (reverse cone) and your graphics was pretty much wrong because the product is always forming a cone when you load a silo.

When I was a lad I worked on both dairy and arable farms, I've even made proper, prize winning and very tasty cheddar cheese wrapped in muslin cloth. We collected about 5,000 gallons of milk from surrounding farms and this was processed into about 40 x 70lb cheese wheels with no additives apart from some salt and the rennet to kick start the process.
Farming is hard work and I feel quite sorry for the many small independent farmers because they really have no time for holidays or breaks because there is always something to be done from feeding the animals to general maintenance around the place.
Yet few farms (if any) around where I live ( south-west England) grow food any more and even fewer farms produce milk. I even returned to the cheese making farm where I had worked about 35 years before.
The farm still makes cheese but it's now wrapped in plastic and tastes horrible, in fact, it's an insult to call it cheese.
Most if not all the farms around my region mainly grow: Oils seed rape, crops for the biodigester like maize, wheat and turnips or elephant grass for the animal bedding industry, farms are run by 3 or 4 people and seem to be owned by corporations or conglomerates.
The county council owns many of the farms and have been selling them off to bigger farming enterprises and booting out the tenant farmers because they no longer give them a big enough return and two of the farmers I know personally and they had been growing organic produce which takes many years to get going and the food is worth it's weight in gold unlike most commercial food and meat which isn't.
The problem is subsidies, yet why should farmers get subsidised for doing their jobs? I don't in my capacity as a conservation builder where I try to use sustainable materials like wood and hair (for fibres) or wool for insulation.
Many farms could not exist without subsidies yet if my business did not make a profit (and mine does not, it just about covers my bills) I would be on benefits or out on the street.
The other huge problem is the heavy machinery and the chemicals and fertilisers needed to run the farm and make things grow and if your farm uses GMO's then heaven help the land because these are of no benefit whatsoever to the microorganisms and worms needed to make the soil healthy and without these the food has little (if any) nutritional value and by using products like RoundUp they have even less, especially the livestock fed on it.
There is too much food waste because of sell-by dates and supermarkets demanding blemish free fruit and veg or straight cucumbers etc.
By continuing as we are with farming practices the land will be almost unusable within 50 to 60 years and we only have ourselves and the supermarkets and corporations to blame along with the governments for failing to do anything except to help worsen the situation.
Time to change, time to RE-WILD all the farms.

Long story:
Years ago I had a friend tell me he was excited for the game Farming Simulator 2013. I thought he was messing with me. A few months later it came out and he played it all the time to the point that I needed to buy it to play games with him again. Months later, we were spending hours in the game, just tending to our crops. The math, logistics, economics, business, mechanical engineering, etc. that the game required blew my mind. I thought "Farming? How hard can it be? Farmers are dumb. I'm smart. This will be easy." Boy, was I wrong. It may have just been a game, but it gave me a new respect for farmers after seeing what went into their daily lives and how it all worked. Which, as the old saying goes, "You never really know someone until you walk a mile in their shoes."
FASCINATING!!!

You always hear people say that farm kids are great to hire, and I can tell you why.  It's not because we work harder, but it's the ability to think outside the box.  As the video shows, you don't call someone, you find or make the tools you need and fix it.  This thought process translates into any job you do.  I'm in my 50s now, and I'm in commercial construction, and get almost annoyed at people who, when things don't go exactly as planned, get frustrated instead of thinking their way to a solution.  Don't worry about HOW things are screwed up, because it's gotta get fixed so just fix it.  That's the biggest thing my dad ever taught me.

And on the 8th day, God looked down on his planned paradise and said, "I need a caretaker." So God made a farmer.

God said, "I need somebody willing to get up before dawn, milk cows, work all day in the fields, milk cows again, eat supper and then go to town and stay past midnight at a meeting of the school board." So God made a farmer.

"I need somebody with arms strong enough to rustle a calf and yet gentle enough to deliver his own grandchild. Somebody to call hogs, tame cantankerous machinery, come home hungry, have to wait lunch until his wife's done feeding visiting ladies and tell the ladies to be sure and come back real soon -- and mean it." So God made a farmer.

God said, "I need somebody willing to sit up all night with a newborn colt. And watch it die. Then dry his eyes and say, 'Maybe next year.' I need somebody who can shape an ax handle from a persimmon sprout, shoe a horse with a hunk of car tire, who can make harness out of haywire, feed sacks and shoe scraps. And who, planting time and harvest season, will finish his forty-hour week by Tuesday noon, then, pain'n from 'tractor back,' put in another seventy-two hours." So God made a farmer.

God had to have somebody willing to ride the ruts at double speed to get the hay in ahead of the rain clouds and yet stop in mid-field and race to help when he sees the first smoke from a neighbor's place. So God made a farmer.

God said, "I need somebody strong enough to clear trees and heave bails, yet gentle enough to tame lambs and wean pigs and tend the pink-combed pullets, who will stop his mower for an hour to splint the broken leg of a meadow lark. It had to be somebody who'd plow deep and straight and not cut corners. Somebody to seed, weed, feed, breed and rake and disc and plow and plant and tie the fleece and strain the milk and replenish the self-feeder and finish a hard week's work with a five-mile drive to church.

"Somebody who'd bale a family together with the soft strong bonds of sharing, who would laugh and then sigh, and then reply, with smiling eyes, when his son says he wants to spend his life 'doing what dad does.'" So God made a farmer
~Paul Harvey~

"The US National Library of Medicine" Authors Robin Mesnage & Michael Antoniou,
"FACTS AND FALLACIES IN THE DEBATE ON GLYPHOSATE TOXICITY" (Published 2017 Nov.24th)
Abstract:-
The safety profile of the herbicide glyphosate and its commercial formulations is controversial. Reviews have been published by individuals who are consultants and employees of companies commercializing glyphosate-based herbicides in support of glyphosate’s reapproval by regulatory agencies. These authors conclude that glyphosate is safe at levels below regulatory permissible limits. In contrast, reviews conducted by academic scientists independent of industry report toxic effects below regulatory limits, as well as shortcomings of the current regulatory evaluation of risks associated with glyphosate exposures. Two authors in particular (Samsel and Seneff) have published a series of commentaries proposing that long-term exposure to glyphosate is responsible for many chronic diseases (including cancers, diabetes, neuropathies, obesity, asthma, infections, osteoporosis, infertility, and birth defects). The aim of this review is to examine the evidential basis for these claimed negative health effects and the mechanisms that are alleged to be at their basis. We found that these authors inappropriately employ a deductive reasoning approach based on syllogism. We found that their conclusions are not supported by the available scientific evidence. Thus, the mechanisms and vast range of conditions proposed to result from glyphosate toxicity presented by Samsel and Seneff in their commentaries are at best unsubstantiated theories, speculations, or simply incorrect. This misrepresentation of glyphosate’s toxicity misleads the public, the scientific community, and regulators. Although evidence exists that glyphosate-based herbicides are toxic below regulatory set safety limits, the arguments of Samsel and Seneff largely serve to distract rather than to give a rational direction to much needed future research investigating the toxicity of these pesticides, especially at levels of ingestion that are typical for human populations.

Keywords: glyphosate, chronic disease, pesticides, toxicity, glycine, gluten sensitivity, cytochrome P450 enzyme system, microbiome

I loved this video. I grew up on a farm in NW Oklahoma for the first 20 yrs of my life and I gotta tell you it was FUN running combine. That is by far one of my favorite pastimes. I often tell people that growing up on a farm is the best class of physics you’ll ever get. On our farm we hardly ever used our grain bins because the local co-op or elevator would store it for us. Then we could sell it when ever we felt the price was right.

Also you can ask your farmer friend about this too but there are a multitude of options that make it even easier to monitor your grain. I’ve seen bins that have vertical augers installed for stirring the grain. There’s also moisture and temperature probes that hang from the roof of the bin in different locations to give you an average reading. It’s absolutely cool what all is available.

You should listen to that farmer when he says "We're not all that smart"! Think about it, today's farmers depend heavily on technology. That technology is designed so that a 5 y/o can use most of it - it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out the basics of using a grain storage bin, or drive a tractor, or to drop off soil samples to the county ag dept., and many kids today can operate electronic gizmos better than the people who invent them. These farmers have numerous assets at their finger tips that answer any question they have about anything agricultural - it's called the county agricultural extension service, which is paid for by tax dollars! Today's farmers are also heavily subsidized by the government, which is paid for by tax dollars. Another thing that is characteristic of today's farmers is that most of them are commodity farmers who produce mono-crops, and they are financed to the hilt (with government backed low interest loans - subsidized by tax payers) with all of the machinery and infrastructure that they need to be competitive; they rely on all of this infrastructure and technology so they don't have to work so hard. If farmers were actually as smart as you think, then there would NOT be such a turn over in farming - meaning that many farms go bankrupt every year, and often because of poor management decisions, which includes being wiped out by a single natural event, like what happened this year in the midwest - because they seldom plan ahead in case of a bad year. That last farmer told you that he relies on several other people who do marketing, etc. and without doing that most farms would go under. If you really want to see what true farming is, then find a smaller operation that produces a wide variety of seasonal crops. Some of these smaller operations make better profit margins than the mega farm operations because they are producing a product YEAR 'ROUND and harvesting every day, instead of getting one (maybe) two huge crops per year, and they do it with far less infrastructure and far less technology with far less expense.


I have nothing against farmers, because I am one (on a very small scale), but these mega farmers, who farm thousands of acres are NOT real farmers. I worked for one of these "mega" farmers for a year right after retiring from the military because I wanted to see if I wanted to be a farmer --- and if you had them write down everything they do in a day for that whole year, they have VERY LITTLE time down doing farming!

Hey Destin, You need to plant your sweet corn(ses) in more rows.  There are 2 reasons for this: 1 - the corn along the outside of the patch doesn't do as well (more competition with other species - in your case your yard) and 2: Corn is an "open pollinated" crop that relies on the wind to move the pollen to the silks to fertilize the grain. If you don't have many rows, that makes it harder for the wind to pollinate the crop as you end up blowing a lot of the pollen into your yard (and not onto the crop). Learned this the hard way myself. If you don't want to raise a huge crop, plant shorter rows in a square plot so that your plot is more rows "wide" and I bet the ones in the center do real well. Good luck with the garden and thank you for shining this much needed light on the ag community. God bless.

I used to write code for a company that makes these automated air vent systems. We used cables with sensors of humidity and temperature that came from the ceiling all the way to the floor. This way the fans would turn on automatically, to keep the grains dry and at the right temperature, and to reduce the risk of spontaneous combustion.

Been there, done that - working on a farm paid for my college.  Folks just don't understand how hard the work can be, how risky (both physically and financially), and how stressful it can be. Forty hour work week?  Pshaw, we'd hit that Tuesday afternoon. I worked 100+ hour weeks during seeding and harvest.  The closest place to get parts was 40 miles away so you had to be very careful, and we often came up with creative field fixes to keep things running until someone could go get replacements.   Oh, yeah, the closest medical facility was 40 miles away as well, so you really, REALLY had to be careful around the machines, on ladders, etc.  There was much that I enjoyed and miss (getting out in the fields at sunrise really makes you appreciate the beauty of the world), but other careers called me and I left the farm fondly behind.

My late father-in-law grew up on a farm, and majored in agronomy for at least the first two years of college. He eventually became a doctor, and was ultimately quite successful, but he invested in farms and made most of his money on these investments. When he died his kids inherited his last remaining farm, and one of the sons thought he could run it in his spare time! Having spent years talking to my father-in-law about crop insurance and when to sell his corn, and lots of other related things - as well was watching how much time he spent on managing his farm (he had someone who actually did the farming for shares) - I encouraged my wife to vote to sell, since all of the kids had busy careers of their own, and none of them knew as much as I did about farming (and all I knew was how much there was to know, and that I knew none of it). Fortunately, the brother who wanted to run it (he actually asked "How hard can it be?") needed money for his daughter's medical school, so in the end they sold while the farm was still in top condition and land prices in the area were high.

Destin, one of the reasons why your corn hasn't done well (I'm assuming you've planted and kept the same size plot every year for your corn as in this video) is that the border of grass around your corn is too CLOSE.  Think of the amount of water that grass takes....just to keep it green.  Then, think about what corn is primarily comprised of....the individual grains that is.... WATER.  Plus, grass takes a great deal of nutrients to keep it green as well as water...think about the root system of grass vs. corn.  They're similar is size and composition. Not exact but similar.  Also, another consideration is the type of grass you have....looks like a variety of Bermuda.  Bermuda sucks a LOT of water.  Theme here is WATER.  You've obviously come to the conclusion that the border of grass around your corn plot is too narrow.  Experiment.  The grass sucks the water away from the corn decreasing growth and a few other things.  Corn requires a "goldilocks" amount of water.  The grass around your corn narrows your margin for error for that "goldilocks" zone.  So, widen the dirt border around the corn and see what happens.  Also, plant some marigolds at the border around the corn.  They a natural insect repellent that lowers the insect pests around your corn.  Great for potatoes and potato bugs (those are the WORST) too!  Smarter every day, eh?

I used to build water tanks for farms in Australia which were built very similar to this. We went from the bottom upward and used external columns to bolt the sheets together that were pre-assembled with threads for the bolting. Then we would use trusses and a specifically designed crane to do the roof. Then the liner is unrolled once the roof is up so it doesn't get damaged by the sun. Nowhere near as safe as this method but not as large as the bins either. Now I'm a mechanical engineer.

Also we call a "punch" a podgy bar (or a pinch bar) in Australia! The most useful fitting tool you can have.

I recently saw a video, on YouTube, wherein they were demonstrating a rescue device for someone trapped in a grain bin. They left the auger on long enough for the demonstrator to become trapped, and then showed that the trapped person could not dig out, or be dug out, even with help because the grain keeps filling back in. He could not be lifted out either without pulling his arms out of socket.
They were demonstrating a cylinder, maybe 6 foot tall, and 2.5 or 3 feet in diameter. It is lowered around the trapped person, and worked down in to the grain as far as possible. It acts like a cofferdam which then allows the trapped person to dig himself out with a scoop, or bucket, without the grain filling back in. It was very interesting.

Interesting if this is a dialect thing or what, but I've never called those punches. For me, it's called a punch if the tip is just strictly cylindrical, not tapered. Those tapered ones I've always called "drift pins", since you can use them to "drift" the holes into alignment. I was a city boy who spent summers with his cousins in Indiana farm country. Being a sci/math nerd, I was unprepared for the physical (and allergy) demands, but was totally prepared for the science demands.

Do you know the math of stacking straw bales vs. stacking hay or alfalfa? Do you know when a conveyor belt is better than an auger? Do you know when (and why) sisal twine is used for baling, and other times wire is used instead? Do you know why a tractor will never tow more than two flatbed trailers? Do you know when sprinklers are preferred over gravity irrigation?

Do you know why farmers wear long-sleeved shirts and long pants even on the hottest days? Did you know that corn leaves can cut like a knife? Destin;  farming ranks high on the  "dangerous jobs " list !   A neighbor and friend lost a family member in a grain bin accident !  I grew up on a farm and was operating all sorts of  equipment - from tractors to mowers to combines and balers - by the time I was twelve.  As a teen when  my peers were dreaming of driving I was - everything from tractors to trucks in the fields and on the roads.  There's also some  'hidden dangers'  in farming'  from " brown lung " due to breathing dust and chaff, to chemical poisoning from mishandling of pesticide3s and herbicides, to plain old  ' petroleum poisoning'  from contact/ingestion/injection of petroleum products .  Add to that the 'ordinary hazards'  of working in confined spaces,   dealing with large animals,  dealing with electrical machinery  (  other friends lost their daughter to electrocution moving a grain auger ) and exposure to wind and weather in addition to field hazards ( our area  lost its share to tractor rollovers/runovers,  PTO incidents and at least one limb to harvest machinery I recall )  and  mising fingers weren't remarkable .   Great video and thanks for  sharing the " price of food "  for those lacking any knowledge of " the cost of living "  !

AWESOME vid!  I have always wanted to follow my dad's family in farming, but when you look at all the data they sift through, all the knowledge and skills, it's overwhelming!  When dad was moving back to my state, we went to my uncle's to help load everything into a horse trailer.  To do that we needed a working tractor, and it just so happened my uncle was in the middle of repairing it.  I had to help since my arms are smaller than his, and he was explaining to me how John Deere has started making it harder to get inside their machines in order to force farmers to go to John Deere mechanics to fix them.  It reminds me of my car battery when my uncle tried charging it.  The old cars you can easily get to the jump points on the battery, but the newer models stuff the battery behind everything so the only way to get to it is to have a professional mechanic remove all the parts.  That's a labor cost passed on to the consumer each time they need to replace a car battery rather than the older models which you could do the labor yourself in 5 minutes in a Walmart parking lot.

Another interesting engineering problem: What happens when these catch fire, or when someone is stuck in one and you have to offload 20-40,000 bushel of grain or seed fast? They are designed specifically to hold low density material. You can't fill them up with water because they'll catastrophically rupture. If someone is stuck and you have to offload grain quickly you have to cut two holes in the panels opposite each other so the grain offloads evenly otherwise, again, it will rupture catastrophically. The design uses the grain itself to support the structure when it's full. Neat stuff. Another cool thing about grain: the angle of repose.

I used to manage a production farm for Olathe Kansas "Peaches and Cream" sweet corn, and yeah, in reference to your comment on growing corn it is a pain. It takes about 300 gallons of water roughly to grow a productive plant. For a small garden or microfarm I'd recommend putting it in raised plasticulture beds spaced about 18 inches apart between the plants. Run a drip line or a punctured water hose along each line so you can water them in the mornings. It'll give you a great harvest of some great vegetables.

They use something similar to the punch to align structural steel when building steel framed buildings. It has a crescent wrench on one side, and a tapered spike for the handle. Its sometimes called a "construction wrench". They use it for the same purpose as those little punches, but on beams that can weight several tons.

You should look at growing the three sisters, natives grew corn, squash, and beans together. The idea is that the squash provides ground cover that helps hold in the moisture of the soil, the corn provides a pole for the beans to climb up, and the beans provide nutrients to the soil. They form their own little ecosystem, but it's pretty challenging to grow. A lot of native people I know still grow their three crops this way.

Destin! I was hoping you would mention this in your video, but those farmers failed to mention to you that another dangerous aspect of grain storage is that it's one of the most explosive environments you can be in!! I work for a fire suppression company, and we service many explosion suppression systems for grain elevators.  it's insane how much energy a grain dust explosion has!!      the ironic thing is, our systems actually use explosions to suppress the explosions 😁 after a specified pressure spike occurs, using an adjustable pressure switch, it activates a small detonator, on a pressurized sphere full of a dry powder agent that extinguishes the flame front of the explosion reducing its energy.  pretty cool stuff. Have a good one! I always enjoy your videos! 👍

"The grains consumed a couple thousand years ago bear little to no resemblance to the grains we consume (or don’t consume!) today. In that time, there were only three major types of wheat in existence: Einkorn, Emmer, and later Triticum aestivum along with simple, non-hybrid varieties of other grains like barley, millet, and rye. These grains had (and still have) a higher protein content and lower anti-nutrient content than grains of today.


"This is a stark contrast to the 25,000+ species that exist today, most of which we created in a lab to be disease resistant or produce high yields. In order to achieve these traits like disease and pest resistance, scientists had to enhance the part of the grains that naturally resists disease and predators: mainly, the glutens, lectins, and phytates- the most harmful parts of the grains to humans. In addition, these hybridized strains are often allergen producing and usually sprayed with pesticides and chemicals.


"It is interesting to note that some people who are allergic to modern strains of wheat show little to no reaction to (properly prepared) Einkorn wheat in small amounts. So, the grains of about two thousand years ago weren’t genetically similar to the grains of today, and had lower concentrations of the harmful components. In addition, they were prepared much differently...."
----------

I just want to highlight just how small the profit margin really is. Two five gallon buckets full of beans is currently worth around $9 in Minnesota. A lot of people look down on farmers thinking that the job is just dirty grunt work and waiting around when in reality there's a lot of technical nuances to it that no college will ever teach you. Depending on what kind of farming one does, they're looking at operating and tweaking automated systems, machinery maintenance, plumbing, construction, and operating heavy machinery without destroying it. This is on top of the fact that a farm is a business, so there is an incentive to know basic economics, accounting, investments, and even some statistics (and if they're a really big farm that requires hiring employees, now they've got management balanced on top of it) And considering that what they're producing is food, they also want to ensure sanitation levels are sufficient or else they'd be shipping out contaminated food which may lead to legal consequences.


All in all, they aren't specialists in each of the fields mentioned, but they have to know enough of it and balance it all together for a farm to not just operate but to operate efficiently and turn a profit.

Destin, in some applications with cereal grains like barely or wheat, we actually pull the air down through the bin. I've been told this is to prevent  water vapor condensation in the top of the flow cone. As well as to lower the heat / humidity  that would focus near the top surface in the cone. We don't completely level off  all of the top of the pile when we are done filling the bin (safety,  misery). We also put in as much grain as possible therefore,  there is always a cone that will focus heat or humidity. Surface tention, capillary action, convection? I don't know how it works exactly.  We do level a small part of the very top of the cone if it can be reached safely to increase the surface area and allow vapor to escape.

"Farmers are the backbone of America." Don't be so local! Without farmers, the WORLD stops! Here in Western NSW silage is stored in pits not silos. The silage flattened with a heavy roller as it goes in until the pit is full, then the soil removed to make the pit is spread over the top and compacted. For hundreds of thousands of years, the driving factor of humanity was finding enough food to survive. It's only been since the industrial revolution that we've had more food than we know what to do with. Because of that over abundance it's easy to be complacent and downplay the importance of farmers and farming but they are perhaps the most important job. Think of a large city like New York City and how much food it takes to feed that population. Then consider where that food comes from. It doesn't come from NYC because there is not enough space to grow crops there. For every square kilometer of urban city, you need hundreds of kilometers of arable land to support it, and you need a farmer to turn that land into food that goes on your plate.

For your corn, try the three sisters method. Plant beans that will grow up the corn stalk and squash that will cover the ground under the corn. The beans will restore to the soil the nutrients that the corn needs and the corn will return the nutrients for the beans. The squash will give the corn and beans nutrients that they need and will use what they return. The squash will also preserve moisture in the soil and all three will repel pest for each other.

Hey Destin! Try manually pollinating your corn. When corn is grown in small patches it needs to be hand pollinated because the plants arent packed tight enough for that to happen. Corn Fields use the wind, small patches require hand pollinating. When the tassel on top drys  shake it into a curved piece of paper and then blow some onto the silky hairs that appear between the stem and leaves. Without pollination the cobs will have ill formed or missing kernels!

Just to answer your question: there are lots of humidity (and humidity+temperature) sensors around, like DHT11, DHT22, AM2302. Add a 16x2 character LCD panel and some microcontroller (if you're lazy, and Arduino mini), power it from a battery, put these into a plastic box, and you got your moisture meter for around $10.
You could put some of these into your grain bin/silo (just the sensor, maybe a uC, wired), and power off the vents when needed. Or monitor the whole stuff remotely or whatever is necessary.

I read a book on Buckminster Fuller who was an inventor and visionary in his time (creator of the geodesic dome, coined the term "spaceship Earth", and "Bucky balls" were named after him). One of the problems he attempted to solve was the affordable housing. The creation of that came out of this was what he called the "Dymaxion House". It could arrive in a compact tube, was made of lightweight aluminum (a relatively new material at the time), and involved a similar method for easy assembly with limited tools. The assembly method was identical to what you demonstrated here: assemble a section, then raise and repeat. The few geodesic domes that he collaborated on were designed to take advantage of this method.

That punch is similar to a spud wrench.  Thats the tool with a big box wrench on one end and a spike on the other.  It's for ironworkers who raise the I-beam suspension for big buildings.  When the crane lowers in the i-beam, the forces are immense.  So a single ironworker helps align the beam, and uses the back of the spudwrench to align the holes.  Then, you put a bolt into the other hole, pull the wrench out, and use the box end to tighten on a nut.

When I was 19 I worked at an ethenol plant who had huge 500 foot grain bins. My job was to basically clean around the plant and when it got busy during the harvest I would stand out in the sun all day directing trucks on where to go. Coolest part about it was they had what they called the pits and tunnels. Basically it's a series of networks that go underground around the plant to where the trucks drop the grain into a series of conveyor belts. It went about 20 feet underground. It's kinda scary at first to know that a 500 foot silo or bin in right above ground. I also had to climb the stair cases up to the grain bins to clean off around the conveyors. If you laid down on top of the bin you could feel the top of it moving up and down from all the pressure. One day one of the tops of the bin blew off because a sudden change in pressure differentiation due to heat and you'd think we were starting WW3. One of the supervisors was a retired Marine and he just stood frozen in place when we all heard the sound. I think it gave him a PTSD attack for quite a while. To date it was the coolest job I've ever had.

As a 4th generation farmer's daughter (orchardists) thank you for the agricultural video! Please do more on other forms of farming! Also, just in case you hadn't heard about it, corn does best when planted in large square blocks instead of long skinny rows. They need to be surrounded by each other so the wind will blow their pollen onto their neighbors and pollinate their 'flowers'. If they're in skinny rows the pollen mostly gets blown away and you get far fewer corn ears later.  Not sure how or why your corn doesn't always work for you, so just a thought. They're looking beautiful this year though! Thank you for all you do to educate and encourage the world!

IIRC, corn is best grown in clumps/squares rather than thin lines/rectangles. It allows the female flowers to be pollinated better, since there's a bunch of male flowers above each of the female flower. If you plant them in thin rows like that, a lot of the pollen is wasted and just lands on either side of the row.

Worked at the local Grain Elevator as a lumper/pumper. They measure moisture of the grain before purchasing and adjust the price accordingly. It is better have it perfect though. They also check prices in real-time to maximize profit. I saw truck come In buy a truck full of dent corn and park a half mile away only to return two hours later to sell it because the prices were spiking.  He knew something we didn't I guess.

A lot of people don't realize how much all that equipment costs, either. That combine was probably about $250,000, the head (the part that cut the beans down and feeds it into the combine) was another $50,000. Combines are also the most complicated mass produced machines on the planet. That bin was another five or six digits. And, since the machines are getting more and more computerized, the computer portions are getting out of reach due to copyright and security issues.
